task.title: Linking with Relationship Tables in DITA

context.p: A relationship table is used to express relationships between topics outside of the topics themselves. The DITA publishing scripts can then create links between related topics when the content is published. Links are generally created at the end of each topic, though this is up to the publishing scripts.

The reason for using a relationship table is to help make topics easier to reuse. If a topic links directly to another topic, this creates a dependency between the topics. If one is reused in a publication where the other is not used, the link will be broken. By defining relationships between topics in a relationship table, you avoid creating this dependency.

To create an appropriate set of links between topics in different publications, you can create a separate relationship table for each publication. If you are creating different publications by applying profiling conditions to a single map, you can also profile your relationship table.

step.cmd: A relationship table is created in a map. Open the map you want to use in the Author mode. (If the map is currently open in the DITA Maps Manager, double click the map icon to open the map in the editor. If it opens in Text mode, click Author at the bottom left to switch to Author mode.)

Move the insertion point inside the map root element (generally map, but it might be bookmap, or another specialization of the map element). The easiest way to do this is to click below the text of the map and then press the up arrow once. Confirm that you are inside the root element by checking the breadcrumbs at the top left of the editor window. You should see just the name of the root element.
Hit Enter to display the content completion assistant. Choose reltable.
Click the Insert a DITA reltable button on the DITA Maps Toolbar. The Insert Relationship Table dialog is displayed.

Make the appropriate selections in the Relationship Table dialog. See the DITA documentation for a full explanation of the relationship table format and its options. Note that you can change all the selections you make here later using the buttons on the DITA Maps Toolbar or by editing the underlying XML.
To add topic references to your relationship table, drag and drop topics from the DITA Maps Manger or the Project view into the appropriate cell in the relationship table.
